report.title: The Beat of the Soul of Nature
report.author: Kapitan
report.bodytext: I had never had the pleasure of attending one before, but I never /n expected drugs to be sold so openly at music festivals. My journey to /n Spookstock 7 was long an uneventful, and mostly was spent mentally /n preparing for whatever psychedelic experiences I might have. I was /n actually doubtful that I would be able to find any doses at all, as /n it's fairly uncommon in my home state. I was not to be disappointed. /n /n I awoke to the rising sun at about seven o'clock, on the second day of /n the festival. I had arrived at the campground at midnight the night /n before, to something like an all-night music and drug party, and /n hadn't slept much in the intervening time. I was feeling strangely /n refreshed anyway, for some reason. I think it was something about the /n atmosphere of this place; everyone I met seemed to non-verbally /n acknowledge the strange, subtle connectedness that the psychedelic /n state awakens me to. It was, perhaps, the change that was refreshing. /n Not many people I normally interact with have been awakened in this /n way. /n /n As I climbed out of my friend R's car, stretched, and stumbled around, /n I encountered three new arrivals, camped out in the space next to /n us. were yelling at passerby, 'Molly! Mescaline!'. (T-1:00) /n 'Mescaline', I thought. That was definitely on my long, but /n shortening, list of 'Substances To Experience Before I Die'. /n /n In addition to the connectedness, everyone here is just extremely /n friendly, too. Maybe it's all the good pot and beautiful scenery. I /n don't know. Anyway, I talked to this 'mescaline' guy for a while, and /n he invited me over to his campsite, and offered me some hot chocolate. /n He told me that what he actually had was MDMA, Peyote extract, and /n 2C-B, which he explained was like synthetic mescaline. /n /n However, I already knew 2C-B well from my research. I had never /n experienced it, though. It is indeed chemically similar to mescaline, /n but it has its own unique and interesting effects, also. I knew that /n it's effects are described as 'Somewhere between MDMA and LSD, but /n completely unlike a combination of the two.' He agreed to sell me one /n of his few doses. I took it on the spot, and proceeded up the hill to /n the site where people had been gathered around the bonfire the night /n before. I knew there would be a good aura up there. (T0:00) /n /n As a bit of background information, I've been having a mild identity /n crisis over the past few months. A lot of my friendships had changed /n suddenly, and I found myself more alone than I'd ever been. I realized /n at this point that I had been defining myself too much by the people I /n was associating with, and, in the absence of them, I wasn't entirely /n sure who I was, where I was, or even why I was alive. It was very /n disconcerting, to say the least. /n /n The embers of the bonfire of the night before were still smoldering /n when I arrived, and about ten of my fellow early morning trippers had /n been drawn up here as well. They were all sitting around it, smiling, /n sometimes talking sporadically, but mostly just relaxing and being /n generally amicable towards the world. I'd never met any of these /n people before, but the seemed friendly enough. /n /n A kid in glasses and an all-over print t-shirt welcomed me over. This /n was the first time I'd seen the camp in the daytime, and I must say, /n it is beautiful beyond description. It was a perfect day. Clear, blue /n sky with a warm sun beating down its pure energy onto us. The /n greenest, softest grass I'd ever seen encircled the fire like a /n carpet, stretching away into the woods at the bottom of the /n hill. Birds were flying in an unbelievable dance of life far above us, /n as the fire crackled in what I thought was a wise and especially /n soothing manner. I was definitely beginning to feel the effects of the /n drug now. (T+0:30-0:40) /n /n All of my previous trips have been with tryptamine compounds, and what /n I found is that, if 2C-B is any indication, phenethylamines are much /n more pleasant. Much warmer, much friendlier, less 'glitchy', and with /n less distracting visual activity. That's not to say the visual /n activity is not there. If anything, it was much more intense than with /n other drugs I've tried. However, I was able to ignore it much more /n easily. It wasn't as mesmerizing as what I would see on, for /n example, LSD. This was a good thing, as it lets me focus more on my /n soul, which is what I came here to do. /n /n When it finally arrived, after maybe 45 minutes, The come-up was fast /n and fairly intense; almost overwhelming. I felt the energy of it /n washing over me in waves, and it felt amazing. If I had been in a more /n neutral or hostile setting, things probably would have been /n frightening at this point, but I knew that everyone around me /n understood, and was supportive of my state of mind. This made it much /n easier to bare my soul, and slip into a pleasant state of openness and /n unity with my surroundings. (T+0:40-1:00) /n /n Before I had been there thirty minutes, the kid in the glasses and an /n old hippie got together with a guitar and a drum, and started playing /n music. It started off rough, and before long the kid admitted that he /n was 'too fucked up on mushrooms' to be playing guitar well. Everyone /n laughed in that kind of spaced-out way, they switched instruments, and /n then proceeded to play the most beautiful music I've ever heard. The /n trees swayed, the wind blew, the birds swooped and dove in intricate /n patterns, and it seemed as though the whole valley was dancing to the /n beat of our collective soul. /n /n Colors ... are amazing. Acid never did the colors thing for me, but on /n this ... the grass was the greenest green I have ever seen. I'll never /n forget it, as long as I'm alive. The world is a beautiful place, if /n only you can eliminate your bias and stop filtering the beauty through /n your worldview for a moment. I am in love with this place. /n /n The birds ... its almost as if they act as a single organism, some /n kind of a pseudo-hive mind. Every one of them has a soul, but, /n together, they are something greater. Something ... beyond ... mere /n birds. They are a collective. WE are a collective. We are at peace. /n /n It was quickly apparent that 2C-B is also much more of an intoxicant /n than LSD is, at least for me. My memory was dramatically affected, and /n somehow in-sync with the waves of energy crashing over my /n consciousness. The rest of the trip was superimposed upon sets of /n clearly-defined waves of beauty, awareness, and clarity. It was as if /n I was in a movie, and, at points, I would suddenly 'awaken' in a new /n place, as if a cutscene or transition had taken place. I was fully /n sane, conscious, and aware in the intervening time, and I remember it /n clearly, but it's not nearly as important as when I was on the crest /n of a wave of energy. Its as if I was coming to orgasmic revelations, /n every twenty minutes or so. /n /n I remember clearly, at the peak of my come-up, two older clean-shaven /n men came over and sat down around the campfire with us. For some /n reason, it was obvious to me that they were undercover cops. Looking /n back, I'm not sure if they actually were. However, a man in camoflogue /n came over to the campfire, talking in a walkie-talkie, convincing me /n beyond a doubt that we were surrounded by some kind of undercover SWAT /n team. /n /n He reached down behind a log where a kid was sitting, and picked up a /n bag of weed. 'What's this?' he said. 'Will you please stand up, sir?' /n I was sure that we were getting busted, and was really high at this /n point, so it was kind of starting to freak me out. But, it turns out, /n the guy was just selling weed. 'Crappy weed is what it is. Nugget /n delivery service!' he said. 'Somebody buy some nuggets!' I didn't see /n or hear about anyone get arrested during the entire festival. The guys /n that I suspected were cops even smoked some of the pot with us. (T+1:30) /n /n As I started to come down from the crest of my first wave, I wandered /n away from the campfire, and walked down 'Shakedown Street', the place /n where all the vendors are set up. Everyone's face was severely /n distorted, but not in a menacing way. It was an obvious drug effect, /n so it didn't cause me much worry. The people didn't seem to notice /n that I was tripping, or just simply didn't care. I felt a strange /n benevolence towards everyone, tinged with a hint of suspisciousness, /n as I still suspected there were more undercover cops around here, /n somewhere. I didn't have anything on me, so it wasn't a fear, but /n rather an understandable delusion that I held for twenty minutes or /n so. There probably were cops around there, with all the drug /n trafficking going on. However, I recognized it as a drug-induced /n delusion, and brushed it off before I left Shakedown. /n /n Eventually, I ended up by the creek that runs through the bottom of /n the valley. It's nothing like the creeks from my home state, all muddy /n and brown. No, this one was perfectly, unbelievably clear, like in a /n dream. Three more dudes were sitting by the creekside playing drums, /n and again, it seemed like they were playing to the beat of the /n river. Through the music, it seemed to me that they had uncovered the /n secret heartbeat of nature. Why hadn't I heard this before? (T+2:00) /n /n I sat there for nearly two hours, in the sun, listening to the drums, /n the river, and watching the golden spiderwebs of the morning sky dance /n across the perfectly clear water. I bathed in the radiance of the /n heartbeat, its warm, pulsating waves. The energy of that time was /n absolutely amazing. /n /n I find that, personally, with the exception of Ayahuasca, the 'comeup' /n of psychedelics in general is not nearly as useful, in terms of /n introspection, as the 'comedown'. That is, the comeup is more /n enjoyable, but, if I take anything away from the experience, I'm going /n to learn it while descending back to sobriety. That turned out to be /n especially true with this substance. During the last four hours or so, /n I spent a lot of time wandering around, both in the campground, and in /n my mind. /n /n I realized that my identity crisis was more an issue of where I was /n derived from. That is, I need to be part of a collective, a culture, /n perhaps, or a group of friends, but I cannot be OF that culture. Much /n like the flock of birds on the hill, I need to enter into it, /n independently, as a developed person, and bring something new to /n it. Any other way, I would either be defined by cultural norms, or an /n outcast. I need to push out my identity to those around me, rather /n than pulling in theirs. This was my problem, and the realization of /n this greatly settled my soul, and still does, as I write this more /n than a month later. /n /n After the sun had ascended so far into the sky that I could no longer /n justify calling this a 'perfect morning', I ended up back at the /n campsite of the people who had sold me the 2C-B. They were rolling up /n a blunt. Perfect. Everything had that shiny, plastic sheen of order, /n yet identity, about it. They invited me over to smoke. It was a /n wonderful, communal experience. I felt close with everything. I had a /n very intense feeling of having arrived home, at long last. (T+4:20) /n /n There was what seemed to be an extremely long period of intoxication, /n after the main effects had ended. This may or may not have been a /n product of all the marijuana I had smoked over the course of the day, /n though I suspect it was not. I had the same 'waves of energy' feeling, /n but without any of the visual activity, or really anything other than /n a mild feeling of drunkenness. It was not unpleasant in the slightest, /n but it did seem to go on well past the peak of the experience. I was /n just confused as to how I could still feel like I was tripping hard, /n but without any kind of visuals at all. /n /n I finally was completely sober around 3 or 4 PM. The world retained /n its beauty, however, and, strangely, the grass retained its surreal /n green color. Even today, I will occasionally come across a /n particularly green patch of grass in the morning or evening, with the /n sun falling across it just right, and I will again be overwhelmed with /n the beauty of the world. /n /n All in all, I think this was hands-down the best trip of my life. I /n didn't learn as much from this substance as I did from Ayahuasca, and /n it wasn't nearly as intense as LSD or psilocybin mushrooms, but, /n rather, a soft, warm day spent in paradise. I'm glad I had the /n opportunity to experience this. Highly recommended.
